input:
Share blog: fine-tuning FLUX.1 on my face!

Context:
Although large language models (LLMs) seem to get all the attention these days, image-generation models have been advancing just as rapidly. The current state-of-the-art is FLUX.1, an image model from Black Forest Labs (a faction from the Stable Diffusion team). In this article, I share the full process I used for fine-tuning this model to generate unlimited high-quality photos of myself.
writing_steps:
Step 1: Purpose & Audience
- Purpose: Share useful content and promote a new AI tutorial/blog (fine-tuning FLUX.1 image model)
- Audience: AI enthusiasts, technical peers, creators interested in generative AI and personal brand, folks following image models as well as LLMs

Step 2: Post Wireframe
[Engaging hook pulling in readers who may have missed image model progress]
[Short summary of FLUX.1 and the unique project of fine-tuning it on my own face]
[Clear CTA to read the detailed blog/tutorial]

Step 3: Write the body/meat
While LLMs seem to hog the spotlight, image models are rapidly evolving in the background. The latest player is FLUX.1, an open-source image generator built by Black Forest Labs—a spin-out from the Stable Diffusion team.

I recently experimented with fine-tuning FLUX.1... using my own face.

In my new article, I walk you through the entire process—from dataset setup to the fine-tuning scripts, best practices I discovered, and examples of the (slightly uncanny) results.

Step 4: Write CTA
Curious how I did it? Check out the full process in my latest blog.

Step 5A: Brainstorm hook directions
1. [Trend/urgency] "Everyone's obsessed with LLMs, but image models just got a major upgrade."
2. [Personal story] "What happened when I fine-tuned a state-of-the-art image model on my own face?"
3. [Beginner-to-expert clarity] "Most people miss how quickly generative image models are advancing—here's proof."
4. [Problem/solution] "Want unlimited high-quality headshots? Here's how I created them with FLUX.1."
5. [Results/outcomes] "See what happened when I taught FLUX.1 to generate images of me."

Step 5B: Add notes to each direction
1. LLMs get all the attention, but image models like FLUX.1 just took a big leap.
2. Personal anecdote—made my own AI-generated photos, lessons learned.
3. Contrast LLM focus with image model progress.
4. DIY headshots, expansion for creators/personal branding.
5. Show off actual results as proof.

Step 5C: Choose the strongest direction and write hook
Strongest: #2 (Personal story—makes the experience approachable, personal)
Hook: "What happens when you train an AI image model on your own face? I tried it with FLUX.1."

Step 6: Review for style, sequence, voice
- Personal, friendly, technical peer-to-peer
- Clear focus on sharing the journey (not hyping the tool)
- Calls out both the advance in image models and practical, honest experimentation
- Invites readers to take a look, not a hard sell

Step 7: Write the final post
final_post:
What happens when you train an AI image model on your own face? I tried it with FLUX.1.

While LLMs still dominate most AI conversations, image-generation models are quietly making massive leaps. FLUX.1—a new open-source image model from the minds behind Stable Diffusion—just arrived on the scene.

So I decided to put it to the test and fine-tuned FLUX.1 on my own photos, step by step. The result? I can now generate unlimited (slightly uncanny) “headshots” of myself in any setting I want.

In my new blog, I break down the entire process: prepping the dataset, running the fine-tuning scripts, lessons learned, and sample outputs.

Curious how I did it? Check out the full process in my latest article.
